<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 808, 107]]<|/det|> The apparatus for investigating the absorption of the emissions from a radioactive source shown in Fig. 11.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 112, 710, 260]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 273, 515, 292]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 304, 876, 339]]<|/det|> The source and detector are about \(2\mathrm{cm}\) apart. The detector is connected to a scaler, which measures the count rate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 350, 759, 369]]<|/det|> Different absorbing materials are placed between the source and the detector. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 381, 734, 400]]<|/det|> The table below shows the count rate obtained with each of five absorbers. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 411, 688, 542]]<|/det|>
absorbing materialcount rate
counts/s
air523
sheet of paper523
0.5mm of aluminium391
10mm of aluminium214
10mm of lead122

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 107, 94]]<|/det|>
